skills.name: Divide integers up to 2 digits using long division
Divide integers of 3 or more digits using long division
Interpret remainders from written division problems

explanations.A: We need to know how many 6's there are in 84. We start by finding the number of 6's in 8 (tens). We can only take 6 away from 8 once, so the star must be replaced by 1 to represent 1 ten in our answer.
explanations.B: I think you might have subtracted 6 from 8 to get 2. But we need to know how many 6's there are in 8.
explanations.C: I think you might have multiplied 6 by 8 instead of dividing. We need to know how many 6's there are in 8.
explanations.D: I think you might have done 6 ÷ 8, instead of 8 ÷ 6. We need to know how many 6's (the number outside the division 'bus stop') are in 8 (the tens digit under the bus stop).

explanations.A: I think you might have multiplied 4 by 9 instead of dividing. We need to know how many 4's there are in 9.
explanations.B: I think you might have done 4 ÷ 9, instead of 9 ÷ 4. We need to know how many 4's (the number outside the division 'bus stop') are in 9 (the tens digit under the bus stop).
explanations.C: We need to know how many 4's there are in 92. We start by finding the number of 4's in 9 (tens). We can take 4 away from 9 twice, so the star must be replaced by 2, to represent 2 tens in our answer.
explanations.D: I think you might have worked out the remainder when we divide 9 by 4. That number is important but we don't write it above the 'bus stop'. Instead we need to know how many 4's there are in 9.

explanations.A: I think you might have done 6 ÷ 4 but we need to work across from the left and see if there are any tens left that need to be carried over. Ten 6's will give us 60. How much is left to divide when we take this away from 84?
explanations.B: Not quite. We need to work across from the left: 10 lots of 6 will give us 60 so the star will be a '1' to give us 10 in our answer. When we subtract 60 from 84, what are we left with? And how many '6's is that?
explanations.C: We need to know how many 6's there are in 84. We start by finding the number of 6's in 8 (tens). We can only take 6 away from 8 once, so we have 1 ten in our answer (so the star is replaced by a '1'). Subtracting 6 tens from 84 leaves us with 24 under the 'bus stop' that still needs to be divided by 6. There are 4 lots of 6 in 24 so 24 divided by 6 is 4. So the triangle represents 4 in our answer.
explanations.D: I think you might have tried to do 4 ÷ 6. But we need to work across from the left: 10 lots of 6 will give us 60 so the star will be a '1' to give us 10 in our answer. When we subtract 60 from 84, what are we left with? And how many '6's is that?

explanations.A: We need to know how many 4's there are in 92. We start by finding the number of 4's in 9 (tens). We can take 4 away from 9 twice, so we have 2 tens in our answer (so the star is replaced by a '2'). Subtracting (2 x 4 =) 8 tens from 92 leaves us with 12 under the 'bus stop' that still needs to be divided by 4. There are 3 lots of 4 in 12 so 12 divided by 4 is 3. So the triangle represents 3 in our answer.
explanations.B: I think you might have tried to do 2 ÷ 4. But we need to work across from the left: 20 lots of 4 will give us 80 so the star will be a '2' to give us 20 in our answer. When we subtract 80 from 92, what are we left with? And how many '4's is that?
explanations.C: I think you might have done 4 ÷ 2 but we need to work across from the left. 20 lots of 4 will give us 80 so the star will be a '2' to give us 20 in our answer. When we subtract 80 from 92, what are we left with? And how many '4's is that?
explanations.D: Not quite. We need to work across from the left: 20 lots of 4 will give us 80 so the star will be a '2' to give us 20 in our answer. When we subtract 80 from 92, what are we left with? And how many '4's is that?

explanations.A: I think you might have done 3 ÷ 7, instead of 7 ÷ 3. We need to know how many 3's (the number outside the division 'bus stop') are in 7 (the hundreds digit under the bus stop).
explanations.B: I think you might have subtracted 3 from 7 to get 4. But we need to know how many 3's there are in 7 (hundreds).
explanations.C: Not quite. To find the digit that replaces the star, we need to know how many 3's (the number outside the division 'bus stop') are in 7 (the hundreds digit under the bus stop).
explanations.D: We need to know how many 3's there are in 735. We start by finding the number of 3's in 7 (hundreds). We can take 3 away from 7 twice, so the star must be replaced by 2 to represent 2 hundreds in our answer.

explanations.A: Not quite. To find the digit that replaces the star, we need to know how many 3's (the number outside the division 'bus stop') are in 7 (the hundreds digit under the bus stop).
explanations.B: We need to know how many 3's there are in 771. We start by finding the number of 3's in 7 (hundreds). We can take 3 away from 7 twice, so the star must be replaced by 2 to represent 2 hundreds in our answer.
explanations.C: I think you might have done 3 ÷ 7, instead of 7 ÷ 3. We need to know how many 3's (the number outside the division 'bus stop') are in 7 (the hundreds digit under the bus stop).
explanations.D: I think you might have worked out the remainder when we divide 7 (hundreds) by 3. That number is important but we don't write it above the 'bus stop'. Instead we need to know how many 3's there in 7.

explanations.A: Not quite. We need to work across from the left and see if there are any tens left after we have found the star and the triangle. 200 lots of 3 will give us 600 so the star will be a '2' to give us 200 in our answer. When we subtract 600 from 735, we are left with 135. 40 lots of 3 will give us 120 so the triangle will be a '4' to give us 40 in our answer. What are we left with? And how many '3's is that?
explanations.B: I think you might have subtracted 3 from 5 to get your answer but we need to work across from the left and see if there are any tens left after we have found the star and the triangle. 200 lots of 3 will give us 600 so the star will be a '2' to give us 200 in our answer. When we subtract 600 from 735, we are left with 135. 40 lots of 3 will give us 120 so the triangle will be a '4' to give us 40 in our answer. What are we left with? And how many '3's is that?
explanations.C: If we were only dividing 5 by 3, that would work but we need to work across from the left and see if there are any tens left after we have found the star and the triangle. 200 lots of 3 will give us 600 so the star will be a '2' to give us 200 in our answer. When we subtract 600 from 735, we are left with 135. 40 lots of 3 will give us 120 so the triangle will be a '4' to give us 40 in our answer. What are we left with? And how many '3's is that?
explanations.D: We need to know how many 3's there are in 735. Starting with the hundreds, 200 lots of 3 will give us 600 so the star will be a '2' to give us 200 in our answer. When we subtract 600 from 735, we are left with 135. 40 lots of 3 will give us 120 so the triangle will be a '4' to give us 40 in our answer. When we subtract 120 from 135, we are left with 15. Finally, 5 lots of 3 is 15, so the rectangle will be a '5'. This gives 735 ÷ 3 = 245.

explanations.A: We need to know how many 3's there are in 771. Starting with the hundreds, 200 lots of 3 will give us 600 so the star will be a '2' to give us 200 in our answer. When we subtract 600 from 771, we are left with 171. 50 lots of 3 will give us 150 so the triangle will be a '5' to give us 50 in our answer. When we subtract 150 from 171, we are left with 21. Finally, 7 lots of 3 is 21, so the rectangle will be a '7'. This gives 771 ÷ 3 = 257.
explanations.B: Not quite. We need to work across from the left and see if there are any tens left after we have found the star and the triangle. 200 lots of 3 will give us 600 so the star will be a '2' to give us 200 in our answer. When we subtract 600 from 771, we are left with 171. 50 lots of 3 will give us 150 so the triangle will be a '5' to give us 50 in our answer. What are we left with? And how many '3's is that?
explanations.C: If we were only dividing 1 by 3, that would work but we need to work across from the left and see if there are any tens left after we have found the star and the triangle. 200 lots of 3 will give us 600 so the star will be a '2' to give us 200 in our answer. When we subtract 600 from 771, we are left with 171. 50 lots of 3 will give us 150 so the triangle will be a '5' to give us 50 in our answer. What are we left with? And how many '3's is that?
explanations.D: Not quite. We need to work across from the left and see if there are any tens left after we have found the star and the triangle. 200 lots of 3 will give us 600 so the star will be a '2' to give us 200 in our answer. When we subtract 600 from 771, we are left with 171. 50 lots of 3 will give us 150 so the triangle will be a '5' to give us 50 in our answer. What are we left with? And how many '3's is that?

explanations.A: The remainder is 1 and this is the part of 231 that has not yet been divided by 5. What do we get if we divide this remainder by 5?
explanations.B: Not quite. The remainder is 1 which is the part of 231 that has not yet been divided. 5 is the number that we still need to divide it by. What do we get if we divide the remainder by 5?
explanations.C: Not quite. If we were dividing the remainder by 2, we would get 1 ÷ 2 = ½ = 0.5. But we are dividing by 5. How else can we write 1 ÷ 5?
explanations.D: The remainder is 1 because 46 x 5 = 230 and 231 — 230 = 1. This is the part of 231 that has not yet been divided by 5. If we divide the remainder by 5, we get 1 ÷ 5 = ⅕.

explanations.A: Not quite. 0.4 is the same as 4/10 or 4 ÷ 10. But we are dividing the remainder of 1 by 4. How else can we write 1 ÷ 4?
explanations.B: The remainder is 1 because 106 x 4 = 424 and 425 — 424 = 1. This is the part of 425 that has not yet been divided by 4. If we divide the remainder by 4, we get 1 ÷ 4 = ¼.
explanations.C: The remainder is 1 and this is the part of 425 that has not yet been divided by 4. What do we get if we divide this remainder by 4?
explanations.D: Not quite. The remainder is 1 which is the part of 425 that has not yet been divided. 4 is the number that we still need to divide it by. What do we get if we divide the remainder by 4?
